awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Signal Processing Framework for Computational Imaging: From Theory to Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Computational Imaging (CI) has emerged as a powerful tool for the design of imaging systems over a wide variety of applications, including consumer imaging, machine vision, surveillance, remote sensing, and microscopy. The key idea behind CI is that joint design and optimization of optics, sensors and algorithms rapidly enlarges the design space for imaging enabling performance characteristics that were hitherto unachievable. This project develops novel imaging systems that can break through the barriers of size, spatial resolution, temporal resolution, field of view, weight and cost by leveraging on the co-design of optics and signal processing. Imaging as such, has a very broad range of applications spanning consumer/medical/scientific imaging, machine vision and remote sensing. In conjunction with advancing the scientific goals of this project, the project integrates computational imaging and display concepts into several courses offered at Rice University and is developing a summer workshop on imaging to economically disadvantaged high school students and their teachers, thereby increasing K-12 STEM engagement. 

This research develops a signal processing framework for Computational Imaging (co-design of optics, sensors and algorithms), that is based on Gaussian Mixture Models. The model along with associated algorithms, will, for the first time, enable (a) fundamental performance bounds for existing CI systems, (b) make the design process systematic and develop novel CI systems, and (c) characterize and understand the regimes of operation for CI. The research team demonstrates the importance and utility of the framework, by creating order of magnitude performance improvements in three different application areas: (1) lens-free cameras: design, develop and demonstrate thin, lens-free cameras that consist of a  series of masks laid on top of a bare conventional sensor with associated algorithms for demultiplexing; (2) light-in-flight imaging: design, develop and demonstrate ultra-fast imaging using conventional time-of-flight sensors and appropriate illumination/sensor modulation and reconstruction techniques; and (3) high-res, long-range imaging: design, develop and demonstrate sub-diffraction imaging resolution at long ranges, using a camera array and phase retrieval based algorithms.

General Summary

The project aimed to push the boundaries of imaging technology through research in computational photography, imaging through scattering media, non-line-of-sight imaging, and ultra-compact imaging modalities. This report summarizes the project's achievements, highlighting the significant outcomes, methodologies, and potential impact of the research conducted.

The project resulted in:

  1. Advancements in Imaging Technology: The project has achieved significant advancements in imaging technology, including computational photography, imaging through scattering media, non-line-of-sight imaging,ultra-miniature imaging modalities, and microscopy. These advancements have expanded the capabilities of imaging systems, enabling improved image quality, enhanced imaging in challenging environments, and the development of new imaging modalities.

  2. Impact on Real-World Applications: The project's outcomes have practical applications across multiple fields. The advancements in image quality, post-processing, and imaging techniques have impacted consumer photography and professional imaging. The research in microscopy, imaging through scattering media, and non-line-of-sight imaging has implications in medical diagnostics, research, surveillance, autonomous vehicles, and virtual reality experiences. These practical applications highlight the project's significance in addressing real-world problems.

Intellectual Merit 

  1. Computational Photography: The project successfully developed novel algorithms and systems to enhance traditional cameras, resulting in improved image quality, dynamic range, and post-processing capabilities. These advancements have found applications in consumer photography, mobile imaging, and medical imaging, offering affordable and high-performance imaging solutions.

  2. Imaging through Scattering Media: Through innovative techniques and advanced algorithms, the project enabled the capture of high-quality images in challenging environments with heavy scattering, such as imaging through fog (autonomous driving), imaging through skin tissue and skull (medical diagnostics).

  3. Non-Line-of-Sight Imaging: The project's research in non-line-of-sight (NLOS) imaging successfully developed methodologies to recover hidden scenes using indirect reflections of light. By leveraging time-of-flight measurements and advanced algorithms, the project achieved significant progress in NLOS imaging. The outcomes have implications in surveillance systems, robotics, and autonomous vehicles, enhancing the ability to perceive and reconstruct objects beyond the direct line of sight.

  4. Ultra-Miniature Imaging Modalities: The project also focused on the development of ultra-miniature imaging modalities. The research involved exploring new approaches and technologies to create imaging systems with extremely small form factors. By leveraging innovative designs, micro-optics, and miniaturized sensors, the project successfully developed ultra-miniature imaging modalities that can be integrated into compact devices or embedded into various objects and environments. Notable works are FlatCam, PhlatCam, and bio-FlatScope.

  5. Microscopy: The project delved into the field of microscopy, with research focusing on advancing microscopy techniques and technologies. The work involved developing novel computational methods to enhance the resolution, sensitivity, and imaging capabilities of microscopes. The outcomes of the project have potential applications in medical diagnostics, and biological research, enabling researchers to obtain high-resolution images and extract valuable information from microscopic samples.

Broader Impacts

The project has led to broader impacts on several fronts:

  1. Technological Advancements and Innovation: The outcomes of this project have significantly advanced imaging technology, pushing the boundaries of what is possible in terms of image quality, imaging capabilities, and novel imaging techniques.

  2. Practical Applications: The research outcomes have practical applications in various domains, including consumer photography, medical imaging, neuronal imaging, surveillance, and virtual reality. These applications have the potential to improve imaging capabilities and enhance experiences in these fields.

  3. Interdisciplinary Collaboration: The project facilitated interdisciplinary collaboration, bringing together experts from computer science, optics, imaging, and related fields. This collaboration fostered cross-pollination of ideas and techniques, enriching the research outcomes.

  4. Student training: The project has has significantly contributed to the training of graduate and undergraduate students. Graduate students gained hands-on research experience, mentorship, and exposure to cutting-edge technologies, preparing them for successful careers in academia and industry. Undergraduate students were actively involved in research, gaining practical experience and fostering their interest in computer vision and imaging systems. The project emphasized knowledge transfer through conference presentations and publications, honing students' communication skills. The collaborative research environment promoted teamwork and interdisciplinary thinking.

  5. Knowledge Dissemination and Education: The work has contributed to knowledge dissemination through publications, presentations, and academic engagements. The outcomes of the project have been integrated into academic courses and specialized tutorials.

  6. Technology Transfer: Some of the intellectual property that was generated from the project has been licensed for commercial use cases.
